importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of Sarkozy's arrival at prison marks a significant political moment as the first former EU head of state to be jailed, shaking public trust in democratic institutions.
This is the start date of Sarkozy's five-year jail term, marking a pivotal moment in French political history and public perception of accountability.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The two-month period following sentencing during which the court evaluates the release appeal is a critical legal phase affecting Sarkozy's immediate freedom.

keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, former President of France, is the first former head of an EU state to be imprisoned.
Sarkozy was found guilty of criminal conspiracy for accepting illegal payments from Muammar Gaddafi to fund his 2007 election campaign.
The conviction occurred after a legal process in which Sarkozy denied all charges, and his lawyers filed an immediate appeal for release.
Sarkozy will serve a five-year jail sentence, with a likely solitary confinement cell of nine square meters.
He will receive visits three times a week and one daily walk, consistent with solitary confinement protocols.
Presiding judge Nathalie Gavarino described the offences as of 'exceptional gravity', justifying imprisonment even if appealed.
The case has significant implications for public trust in democratic accountability, especially in high-ranking political figures.
Sarkozy's imprisonment follows no other French leader since Philippe Petain being jailed post-WWII, marking a rare event in modern French political history.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy has begun serving a five-year prison sentence after being found guilty of criminal conspiracy for accepting illegal funds from former Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi to finance his 2007 election campaign. He becomes the first former head of a European Union state to be imprisoned, marking a landmark moment in European political accountability. The conviction, upheld by presiding judge Nathalie Gavarino, who deemed the offences of 'exceptional gravity,' is seen as a rare and significant event in modern French history, especially given that no French leader has been imprisoned since WWII collaborationist Philippe Petain. Sarkozy, 70, will be held in solitary confinement in La Sante prison, with limited contact and access to the outside world. His lawyers have filed an appeal for release, which the court will consider within two months. The case has stirred public debate about political integrity, transparency, and the role of former leaders in democratic societies.
title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy starts five-year jail term
